p: Feral pig control. Larval Culex quinquefasciatus use a wide variety of aquatic habitats, but Hawaiian rainforests with porous volcanic substrates and poorly developed stream drainages limit the availability of standing water habitat [ 18, 40, 41]. Feral pigs, which are managed as a game species in many parts of the state, feed on tree fern trunks creating cavities that become ideal larval mosquito habitats when they fill with leaf litter and rainwater [ 8]. At mid and high elevation on the southeastern slopes of Mauna Loa and Kilauea Volcanoes on Hawaiâ€™i Island, where tree ferns are common, larval carrying capacity (K L) is comprised of natural tree cavities and tree fern cavities created by feral pigs. Removal of feral pigs from these rain forests can decrease the abundance of larval habitat, leading to a decrease in vector abundance [ 8, 32]. We simulated this mitigation strategy by calculating a reduced K L based on larval habitats that are not created by feral pigs in mid elevation (see [ 13] and [ 42] for specific values) and used the same value for high-elevation.
